4.6	Compliance Audits

The TRA Tarrant County Water Supply Project performs periodic (at least every three years) audits of covered processes to verify the processes are operating in compliance with the requirements of the RMP Rule.  A compliance audit report is prepared after each audit, and any deficiencies noted by the audit are corrected in a timely manner.

 4.7	Incident Investigations

The TRA Tarrant County Water Supply Project investigates all incidents that could reasonably have resulted in a serious injury to personnel, the public, or the environment.  The TRA Tarrant County Water Supply Project trains employees to identify and report any and all incidents requiring investigation.  An investigation team is assembled and the investigation is initiated within 48 hours of the incident.  The results of the investigation are documented, recommendations are resolved, and appropriate process enhancements are implemented.

4.8	Chemical-specific Prevention Steps - Chlorine

Industry standards are followed at the TRA Tarrant County Water Supply Project to help ensure safe handling of chlorine.  The vendor supplies chlorine via a Department of Transportation (DOT) approved truck.  The process equipment is designed and constructed with state-of-the-art materials and technology utilizing the standards and guidelines of the Chlorine Institute, Compressed Gas Association, American Water Works Association, ASME, ANSI, and other applicable codes.  Workers who perform operations involving chlorine receive training emphasizing safe handling procedures according to the guidelines required by the TRA Tarrant County Water Supply Project.

TRA Tarrant County Water Supply Project
Risk Management Plan
Executive Summary

1.0	Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The TRA Tarrant County Water Supply Project is committed to the safety of our workers, the public, and the environment.  The resources invested in the prevention of accidental releases of hazardous substances demonstrate this commitment.  The TRA Tarrant County Water Supply Project implements reasonable controls, such as training of personnel and the safe design, installation, operation and maintenance of our processes.  Our policy is to make every effort to prevent the release of hazardous substances but in the event of a release, our trained personnel and local emergency response agencies will respond to control and contain the release in a manner that will be safe for workers and will help prevent injuries to the public or the environment.


2.0	Description of the TRA Tarrant County Water Supply Project and Regulated Substances

The TRA Tarrant County Water Supply Project handles two substances regulated by the Risk Management Plan Rule (RMP Rule) in quantities above the threshold quantity - chlorine and ammonia.  


3.0	Hazard Assessment
 
The RMP Rule requires the TRA Tarrant County Water Supply Project to perform a Hazard Assessment of the regulated substances stored and used in the covered processes at the facility.  The TRA Tarrant County Water Supply Project conducted a Hazard Assessment for the Chlorination and Ammoniation Processes. The results of the Hazard Assessment have been formally communicated with the local emergency response agencies. 


4.0	Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

The TRA Tarrant County Water Supply Project maintains a variety of technical documents that are used to help ensure safe operation of the TRA Tarrant County Water Supply Project processes.  Safety data sheets (SDSs) document the physical and chemical properties of hazardous substances handled at the TRA Tarrant County Water Supply Project, including the chlorine and ammonia processes.  The engineering design documents include the operating parameters, the design basis and configuration of the equipment in each covered process, and references to applicable codes and standards.

4.2	Hazard Review

The TRA Tarrant County Water Supply Project performs and periodically updates hazard reviews of the covered processes to help identify and control process hazards.  Checklists are used to guide the hazard review.  These checklists include items to help ensure the TRA Tarrant County Water Supply Project operates and maintains the equipment in a manner consistent with the applicable design specifications, codes, standards, and regulations.

4.3	Operating Procedures

The TRA Tarrant County Water Supply Project develops and maintains operating procedures to define how tasks related to process operations should be performed.  The operating procedures are used to:

1. train employees and contractors, and
2. serve as reference guides for appropriate actions to take during both normal and abnormal process conditions.

4.4	Training

The TRA Tarrant County Water Supply Project trains personnel in the operating procedures to help ensure safe and effective performance of their assigned tasks. A record of all training is maintained to help ensure new and refresher training is provided on a timely basis.

5.0	Five Year Accident History

There has been no accidents or incidents that resulted in injuries to employees, the public, or the environment at the TRA Tarrant County Water Supply Project in the past five years.


6.0	Emergency Response 

The System Name TRA Tarrant County Water Supply Project has prepared a written emergency response/action plan that complies with the RMP Rule, other federal standards and industry guidelines.  This plan has been communicated to the Local Emergency Planning Committee LEPC/EMA and local fire department under the coordination rules of the RMP.


7.0	Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The TRA Tarrant County Water Supply Project continuously attempts to improve the safety of our processes to protect our employees, the public and the environment.  The TRA Tarrant County Water Supply Project incident investigations, employee suggestions and improvements in technology are utilized to update the safety aspects of the processes.
